cyclone.name: IDA
cyclone.current_location: about 100 miles WSW of Negril, Jamaica
cyclone.trajectory: moving northwest across the northwestern Caribbean, then through the central Gulf of Mexico and turning north-northwest toward the Louisiana Gulf Coast
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: southeast Louisiana coast (near/just south of New Orleans)

weather_observation.watch_coast: None at this time (watches may be issued later)
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern U.S. Gulf Coast from eastern Texas through the Florida Panhandle, with the highest threat focused on Louisiana and Mississippi coasts
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (≥39 mph) have a 61 % cumulative chance; gale probabilities ramp up sharply Sunday, with 28 % onset probability in the 72–96 h window and up to 27 % chance of 50-kt (58 mph) winds.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Life-threatening surge of 3–6 ft possible along southeast Louisiana coast, including areas adjacent to the Port of New Orleans as the cyclone approaches major-hurricane strength.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands of very heavy rain could bring 6–10 inches with localized higher totals, creating flash-flood risk in the port area Sunday into Monday.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Very rough seas on the Lower Mississippi River approaches, dangerous rip currents, and the potential for isolated tornadoes in outer rainbands Sunday/Monday.
